label: Letter from John F. Grimke to General [Howe?], May 1778
description: A three page letter written by John F. Grimke to General (Howe?) from a fort located in Sunbury, Georgia. Grimke writes of the defense of a fort in Augusta awaiting attack. Grimke recommends that the General order additional supplies to account for a longer than expected military campaign.

metadata.label: Description
metadata.value: A three page letter written by John F. Grimke to General (Howe?) from a fort located in Sunbury, Georgia. Grimke writes of the defense of a fort in Augusta awaiting attack. Grimke recommends that the General order additional supplies to account for a longer than expected military campaign.

metadata.label: Access Note
metadata.value: For more information and reuse requirements contact Special Collections at Addlestone Library, College of Charleston, Charleston, SC, 29424.

metadata.label: Digitization Specifications
metadata.value: 600 dpi, 24-bit depth, color, Epson Expression 10000XL, Archival masters are tiffs.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
Sunbury May date unknown 1778.
Dr [Dear] General.
I have the Pleasure of informing
you that the Three Majors are arrived with
un[illegible]lped and [unknown?] Heads at the Seat of Urba-
nity and Hospitality. We found every Acquaintance and
Friend Well. - The Defence [defense] that [illegible] [into?]
is [Informing?] to make is more Warm and Formidable than
We had [Necd?] [dect:?] of before I left Fort Howe;
They are fitting Out the [George?] Twenty Gen [general?] ship;
and cutting down two other [illegible] to Seven and Galleys:
You cannot therefore appear too soon upon the
banks of St. Johns, where a strong Post may-
be established and defended by larger Cannon than
you have at present Ordered soon in the Galleys:
Several if [Powder?] would be found of essential Service,
as year Galleys and the Remainder of the Fleet, may lag
in Safety in that Price upon under the Cannon of
[illegible] it is agreeable to you to Order R[illegible]

[End page 1]

More Common and the [Harrington?] which is here [which al-
most in any situation would be a Terror to our Ene-
mies] I shall readily Comply with your Commands which
I wait for. You will also be pleased to [illegible] from
me whether you would [Chance?] that the Water Casks
belonging to the Prizes should be purchased for the  [Men?]
of the Army; as [illegible] Col. [Colonel] Elberts Report of the Country
we are to Pay thro', [through] we shall find great difficulty in
Procuring the Article of Water. But if the [Processes?]
could be employed to any affect in digging
Wells, perhaps, upon reconsideration it would be
found not Eligible to Procure Water by that means
as the wells would be serviceable to us upon our
Return. The present appearance of Affairs promises
Confer Campaign than at first we were be to
Relieve on the inclined to Credit at present- Per-
haps therefore you would find it equally necessary to
order if the Three Hundred Barrels of Pork
from Carolina with a larger quantity of [illegible]

[End page 2]

Purchased at any rate on Egans Pier which with
very little Trouble may serve in lieu of that Article
I also took the Liberty of Recommending that at least on
[Thacisons?] Canteen and Three Hundred Camp letters
be sent for by the [last?] opportunity. The Carolina
Galley is docked at Savannah and is expected here to
day. I shall Repeat your orders to [Henry?] [illegible] day.
I enclose you a Copy of the Articles sent [around?] by
the Schooner from [here?] and if those things should
not have arrived which you feel your want most
Sensibly, I humbly Presume to advise that you should
send Waggons, as the Delay of waiting for them
by the galley and afterwards sending for them by water,
as very [illegible] for the [illegible] of
carrying them. Capt. Nelson send you Two Cols. [colonels]
I have forwarded a letter to you which you will be
Pleased to [illegible] to the Commander of the Galleys.
[Mrs. J?] threatens to answer your Letter. [Illegible] Ruth has
[illegible] and Mrs Nash fills his Place. The Remainder
[illegible] Obtain their Places [illegible] their [illegible]

[End page 3]

To Gen: [general] Howe. May [17?] 1778.

behavior. We Dine upon Turtle tomorrow and Opine
you leave to [illegible] up. I suppose you may have some Cod
Fish stewed Ala mode Calabash ale [Calipoe?] which
will be equally good to 3/4 or [illegible] of the
Camp. I taken my leave of you not with Regret
because I can give you [illegible] of any Return
and more than Declaration of my Esteem and Respect
for you and that I am I hope so as shall be
Dear General
Your very Obt [obedient] Sert [servant]
Most Affec: [affectionate] Well wishes
John F. Grimke AD

We just now are getting to [feast?] upon squashes and
green peas, and Beans. I wish you could partake with
us.

Should you [Garner?] any Powder from Savannah to Sunsbury,
it would be most readily [illegible] in your present [illegible]
and I will take Care to give the Proper Directions should any

[End page 4]
